Positive: A 65-year-old male presents with a history of smoking and a family history of cardiovascular disease. He complains of constant abdominal or back pain that is severe, sudden, persistent, and located in the abdomen, chest, lower back, or groin. The pain may radiate and be associated with a pulsating sensation. Upon physical examination, a pulsating abdominal mass is palpated. The patient also reports feeling dizzy, sweaty, and short of breath. An ultrasound confirms the presence of an abdominal aortic aneurysm measuring 5.5 cm in diameter.
Negative: A 45-year-old female presents with no significant past medical history and a healthy lifestyle. She denies any abdominal or back pain and reports feeling generally well. Physical examination reveals no abnormalities, and ultrasound imaging does not show any evidence of an abdominal aortic aneurysm.
